utterances: Most of it's spent, you know, paying for everything from electricity, to running production lines, to paying the salaries of the workers.
One of the big problems right now is the company isn't earning enough revenue to offset all these costs.
Sales have been staggeringly bad, I think much worse than anybody expected.
Last month, if we go to February, for GM, it was down nearly 53 percent, year on year.
GM lost about $30 billion last year.
So what we've seen is the recession is really putting people off from buying cars.
As you know, it's a very expensive thing to do for people.
And so that means GM just isn't getting the revenue it needs to keep going.
And as GM would point out, other car companies are also experiencing huge drops in car sales from last year.
Absolutely.
I mean, Toyota last month was down 40 percent.
Forty percent.
GM's asking for another $16 billion from the government, and they have until the end of the month to present the White House auto task force with a plan to become viable.
Where is that plan right now?
I'd love to.
It was a 35th anniversary party for one of the most influential books about basketball ever written.
It's called ""Heaven is a Playground,"" and it was written by Rick Telander, who's now a columnist for the Chicago Sun Times.
Back in 2004, he finished a promising second in the Iowa caucuses, then fell all the way to fourth place in New Hampshire.
This time around he finds he still has fans from 2004, people who liked his Two Americas message, people like Nancy Beach(ph) of Portsmouth.
I needed someone that would represent my progressive values, you know, being fiscally responsible but socially progressive.
And right now I the - you know, and I hate to say the top three, but really in the top three Edwards is the only candidate that gives those of us who feel we're not listened to a voice.
On the other hand, there are still folks like Paul Martin of Hampton who doubt Edwards' viability.

The only reason I think Barack is along with Edwards for me is that Barack seems to be - has kind of momentum and I would like to see someone who can get in and can be voted in and will be an agent for change and won't polarize the nation like George Bush has and really kind of believe Hillary Clinton will do.
But Edwards can take heart from the way he's already convinced early doubters, like Linda Finkell(ph) of Rye.
Initially his position against corporations put me off a little bit, but I think you can't negotiate.
You have to sit down and be very strong, and I think he'll do that.
You need someone who will absolutely go to bat against the big corporations, and I think Obama is going to be too conciliatory.
This Granite State tour was just two days, but the candidate held half a dozen events, and the campaign is looking at returning the day after Christmas.
It's hard to take time away from Iowa with the caucuses just two weeks away.
But John Edwards knows better than most just how long the road to the nomination really is.
Audie Cornish, NPR News, Manchester, New Hampshire.
Allen Iverson is back in the NBA and back home in Philadelphia.
The 10-time All-Star had spent three years with three other teams and a few weeks out of the league entirely.
Well, this week, he took the court for the team that drafted him more than a decade ago, the Philadelphia 76ers.
At a news conference to announce his return, Iverson tearfully insisted that at age 34, he is not done yet.
You know, I didn't want to come back and embarrass myself.
You know, I know I can play and I'm going to prove that.
Well, joining us, as he does most Fridays, is our regular commentator, sportswriter Stefan Fatsis.
Hey, Stefan.
Hey, Michele.
So now that Iverson is back home, how's he doing?
Well, he got a little rust.
He scored 11 points in each of two games in Philadelphia this week.
He made just seven of 21 shots, which is even worse than his already lousy career shooting percentage.
It's not fair to evaluate him on two games, though.
He had played in just three games before leaving the Memphis Grizzlies earlier in the season.
And for those missing weeks, it look like might have to retire because nobody wanted him.
Also, you got to factor in the Philadelphia 76ers are not a very good team.
They lost both games this week, their 10th and 11th losses in a row.
So the hope here is maybe get better on the court but also energize the fan base and it worked in the first game.
Iverson played before a packed house of more than 20,000.
He ran out and kissed the Sixers logo at center court.
The second game though, just 12,000 fans showed up so it's not clear how much of an Iverson effect there's going to be.
Now, while Allen Iverson returned, another NBA player made an exit.
Greg Oden was the top deck of the NBA draft back in 2007.
Tell us a little bit more about him.
Well, he's a 7-foot center drafted to the Portland Trail Blazers.
He missed his rookie season after having surgery on his right knee.
He missed 20 games with right foot and left knee injuries last year.
And then on Saturday night, he fractured his left knee cap and will now miss the rest of this season.
You know...
Ouch, that hurts just hearing about that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, and the picture when you see his knee, it's a little gruesome.
I watched the highlights: There was no contact, no awkward landing, his kneecap just slipped out of place.
And it does remind you just how great the pressures are on the bodies of athletes, especially 7-footers who might not be designed to withstand this kind of stress.
And it's sad for Oden, too.
He's by all accounts a very likable and thoughtful guy.
After the game, he apologized to his teammates.
He said he felt he had let them down.
So, some letdowns in the NBA.
Tell us about someone who's actually doing well right now.
Well, Kevin Durant, 6-foot-9 forward with the Oklahoma City Thunder, and that's the team that moved from Seattle a couple of years ago.
Durant is having a spectacular year.
He's third in the league in scoring with 28 points per game.
The Thunder, as a team, won just 23 out of 82 games last year.
This year they're 11 and nine, in plus territory.
But what's really interesting about Durant is how he has answered back on the floor in a very modern stats debate that really shows how he's improved.
So what's the retort?
Well, the stat is called Adjusted Plus/Minus, and it measures how a team performs when a player is on the court versus when he's off it.
Last year, Durant was proved to be a bust in this category.
The Thunder played worse as a team when he was on the floor.
And when the NBA blogger, Henry Abbott of ESPN, wrote about it in the off-season, Durant actually responded on his Twitter feed, saying, hey, I just played a game.
I don't know about any plus/minuses.
This year, though, his performance has indicated that he does get it.
Abbott reports that the Thunder are giving up 11 1/2 fewer points for every 100 possessions when Durant is on the floor than when he's not.
And they're scoring almost 14 points more when he's on the floor.
Those are really impressive numbers.
Now, Stefan, it's not that I'm stalking you but I understand that you attended a party in New York City this week, celebrating a brand of basketball a world apart from the NBA.
Care to tell me about that?
Yeah, I think you did.
I kept...
This morning, outside the nations capital, 184 men, women and children were remembered at the dedication of the Pentagon Memorial.
As they did after the attack, rescue workers unfurled a huge American flag across the buildings west wall at the point of impact.
(Soundbite of song Amazing Grace)
And a bagpiper played as he walked through the memorial, a two-acre park with maple trees and rows of long, sleek, stainless steel benches, one bench for each victim.
An emotional Donald Rumsfeld, the former Secretary of Defense who was at the Pentagon on September 11th, paid tribute to the victims.

They were men and women at their desks in the Pentagon who one morning kissed their loved ones goodbye, went off to work and never came home, and they were the passengers and crew aboard Flight 77 who in the last moments made phone calls to loved ones and prayed to the Almighty before their journey ended such a short distance from where it began.
President Bush called the memorial a graceful monument, both a tribute to those who died and to those who now serve.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH (United States): Well always honor the heroes of 9/11, and here at this hallowed place we pledge that we will never forget their sacrifice.
We also honor those who raised their hands and made the noble decision to defend our nation in a time of war.
The Pentagon Memorial is the first of three major September 11th remembrance sites to be completed in the seven years since the attacks.
Beginning tonight, it will be open to visitors 24 hours a day.
I spoke with NPR's Scott Horsley earlier from a John McCain rally in Birmingham, Alabama.
I asked him if it's fair to call it a two-candidate race between Romney and McCain.
Since Florida, of course, former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani has dropped out and endorsed McCain.
And since Huckabee has been so far been unable to build on his early victory in Iowa, there's some question about his role in the race.
But of course he could be very competitive in some of the southern states coming up on Tuesday.
And the longer he stays in he probably draws more support away from Mitt Romney than he does from John McCain.
One of the biggest turns in this race was when John McCain suddenly became a winner again when he was just written off last summer.
I mean, now he's the frontrunner.
Of course, that's a dangerous word seemingly in this campaign season.
But he certainly seems to be the leading candidate among Republicans and he has the campaign scheduled to prove it this weekend.

And he's doing that in part through a series of high-profile endorsements from folks like Rick Perry, the governor of Texas and Ted Olson, the former solicitor general, who's prominent in conservative legal circles.
Romney, Mitt Romney, went to a funeral today, the funeral of Gordon Hinckley, the former head of the Mormon Church.
What has Romney's strategy been in the days leading up to the Super Tuesday?
That's right.
The funeral of Gordon B.
Hinckley took Romney off the campaign trail for the lion's share today.
He does have a campaign event in Minnesota tonight.
His is kind of the mirror image of the John McCain strategy.
Instead of going for the winner-take-all states, he's looking for those states where he can, even with a second place finish, keep enough delegates to stay in the hunt.
